div.p:
William Spear called here this morning and told me that his brother had got poisoned last week in the woods, with dogwood— That his face was so much swollen and inflamed that he could not see, out of his eyes; and that he would not be able to hold the Sale of Lots of standing wood, advertised for next Thursday. As the advertisement has been sent into the neighbouring towns, he thought the sale could not be postponed, and proposed that it should be made by Minot Thayer of Weymouth in his place; to which I assented. He said this dogwood poison generally kept a person confined about a week— Mr Rufus Davenport was here, with one of his pamphlets for which I
had subscribed, entitled “Right Aim” chiefly to urge the abolition of imprisonment for debt, and with proposals for other subscriptions, to be confined to the Ladies— I did not incline further to countenance this mode of mendicancy— In the Nursery I planted three Cross furrows West of the Alley; yet in the Stony barren—Juglans Porcina dulcis—with Chesnuts, Acorns and Apple seeds—one Medford Shagbark, and one English Walnut— Opened four Cross furrows East of the Alley— On this first day of November I observe the foliage of the trees. The leaves have fallen almost entirely from the Elms— They have changed colour upon all the Oaks, but a great part of those on the English Oaks are yet green— Those of the Peach trees, are of a dirty crimson and brown— Many of the young Apple trees yet retain their leaves; and some of them are still green— Those of the young Catalpa, are parched by the frost— I finished reading Pingré’s translation of the Poem of Aratus as translated by Cicero and Grotius— The original Poem is extant; and it is that from which St. Paul quoted half a line, in his Sermon to the Athenians— “For we are also his offspring.” This Poem was also translated into Latin verse, by Germanicus Caesar and by Festus Avienus— Fragments of which works are likewise extant. It is merely a poetical description of the Constellations of the Northern Hemisphere according to the Astronomical system of Eudoxus—but the work of Manilius is of the same kind, and far more comprehensive. But in these works every thing is artificial, fictitious and imaginary— Not one of the Constellations bears the most distant resemblance to the persons and animals from which they were named— With most of them fables of the Grecian Mythology are connected; but there is nothing in the aspect of the Constellations to remind you of them— To understand the Poem of Aratus you must first be perfectly familiar with the Grecian Mythology, and habitually familiar with the Nightly course of the Northern Constellations— The descriptions refer partly to the fabulous persons and their Stories, and partly to the configurations and motions of the Clusters of Stars— It is a poem much like the Loves of the Triangles— Among the Greeks there was Religion also mingled with it— Each of the Planets was a God— Many of the Constellations were families of divinities; and men and women and Animals and even inanimate objects like the Lyre of Orpheus, the sword of Orion, the wheat ear of the virgin, and the Scales of Astraea were all placed among the Stars— The Poem of Aratus may yet afford amusement by comparing its descriptions, with the present courses of the Northern Constellations— Lucretia Spear left us this day— I attempted in the Evening to read an Article in the North American Review; but the Article or I was too sleepy— I read some part of W. Tudor’s Journal.
2. IV:30. Tuesday.

Sent John Kirke to Boston with a Letter to my Son Charles. My brother called here and went to Dedham, where the Supreme Court of the State meet this day to hold their Law term— Nursery— Planted a row of the Druid Juglans, with Chesnuts Acorns, Apple and Pear seeds, and stranger berries—but was principally occupied with S. Farrar in digging up large Stones from the Stony-barren— Had their places filled with mould from the garden; and rows of Stones laid along the borders of the Alley. It gives my Nursery altogether the most whimsical and barbarous appearance possible—and after all; what is to be expected from seed sown in Stony ground— Ebenezer Adams called to recommend his brother in Law Capen to me for the Sale of Apple-trees, and he also recommends other chargeable improvements upon my farm. Elizabeth C. Adams
dined with us and Mr Gourgas came for her in the Evening. After dinner I walked over Mount Wollaston to Alpheus Spear’s, but he was not at home— He has further broken up the ground for my Orchard— On returning home I found William Lee here; he said he was to be married on Thursday Evening at six O’Clock to Mrs M’lean, and repeated the invitation to me, to be present at the Marriage, which I promised, should no impediment in the mean time occur— The news from Europe to the first of October teems with Revolutions— I read this morning Olivet’s Latin preface to the Orations of Cicero and one Section of the Oration for Quintius. The preface complains of the multitude of Commentators upon Cicero, and of the voluminous mass of their useless notes, of which he declares his purpose to select and republish a small portion— He promises a great part of those of Victorius, Manutius, Lambinus and Gruterus, and a large Selection from the Edition of Graevius, many from Fronto Ducaeus, whose learning and elegance he says are universally known. Some from Nicholas Hortensius— He avails himself also of the Clavis of Ernesti; and of recent Commentaries of Jacobus Facciolatus, Marcus Antonius Ferratius; as also of the last Edition of the Orations by Hieronymus Layomursmus, upon the collation of more than two hundred Manuscripts. After a sharp censure upon the hunters of various readings, and the reformers of the text by conjecture, he exclaims, addressing his reader— As for you, draw forth from Cicero, that profusion of clear and perspicuous precepts of living, feeling and speaking well, which will not only add to your learning, but to your eloquence, and which is more desirable than all the rest to your virtue.
3. IV. Wednesday.

John Kirke brought me out from Boston last Evening a box of Chesnuts, Acorns and Sweet-gum Apples, which my Son John has sent me from Washington— I began planting them this Morning, in the furrows East of the Alley, from which the large Stones have been taken up— Few if any of them will come up— They were packed in Bran— All, with the exception of two or three Acorns, floated upon water. The Chesnuts had been very good but are dried up— The Chesnut and Acorn will not bear exposure to the air even for a very few days without losing their weight and their germ. It was but the 25th. of last month that I purchased six Quarts of Chesnuts, of a man from N. Hampshire almost every one of which sunk in water— They have been kept in my chamber closet in a basket, and now at least one half of them float— I never shall have any success in planting while these properties of the seed are overlooked— The properties of the Soil are equally important, and those of the climate cannot be disregarded with impunity— With the Liquidamber Apples, and Chesnuts there are Red, black, Chesnut, Post, and Willow Oak Acorns; which I put into the ground with scarce an expectation that any one of them will come up— With them therefore I planted store of Apple seeds, and of Juglans Porcina, of which as it is a sort of weed among trees I promise myself a plentiful crop— I planted one singular shaped Hickory nut in its external shell, in a flower Pot— The white Oak Acorns which I planted in two glass tumblers the 15th of last Month, have pushed down—their tap roots so that one of them had this Morning reached the bottom of the glass— That is had grown four inches— That glass was out one Night, when there was a copious rain— This afternoon I rode up to Mr Capen’s, and visited his nursery— He has many young apple, Pear, and Peach-trees for Sale. He shewed me
also a variety of apples very large, but mostly worm-eaten— Among the rest, the golden and common Russet, Packham, Seek no further and Governor’s Apple, of the last of which I took one with me— Returning I sought in the Atherton pasture, for the wild pear tree, upon which I found last year several pears, but did not find it— But I did find a few more Atherton Crabs, and in the adjoining old Orchard a tree loaded with a small red Apple resembling in colour and appearance the Virginian Redstreak— Its taste was a mild and pleasant acid though without the flavour of the Redstreak— I gathered some of them to plant. Called at my brother’s as I was returning home, and borrowed of Elizabeth, the genealogical family Chart— Read Cicero for Quintius before daylight, and William Tudor’s journal of his Voyage from Boston to Valparaiso and Lima, in 1823 and 24— It is prefaced by a caution and apology to the reader for the dulness and minuteness of its contents— He was a solitary passenger with Captain Gerry to Valparaiso, and there embarked in the Franklin 74—then commanded by Commodore Stewart, his Sister’s husband— She with her family were then on board— The Journal is dull, and yet not uninteresting— The transitions of climate and Seasons three times in the course of a four Month’s voyage, are well-noted— No accident occurred on board the ships, and only two or three of those sudden and violent alarms to which all Sea voyages are liable— There were gales of wind, but no hurricanes, and breakers but no contact with them— The books that he read on the passage, were little worth, excepting Don Quixote his remarks upon which and upon Cervantes are common place.
4. IV.15— Thursday.

Spear came to speak with me about finishing my plantation of Nuts, and Acorns at Mount Wollaston; which I promised to do next Saturday. H. Hardwick renewed his solicitations that I would sell him small parcels of land, adjoining to him at his house and on the Mount Wollaston farm beach— After visiting my Nursery, and planting two Eastern Cross rows, with Washington Chesnuts, Acorns and Liquidamber buttons, Juglans Porcina Amara. 1 Medford Shagbark, Apple-seeds, Stranger berries, and floating, White Oak Acorns, I went with S. Farrar to the Field, Joy, and Borland lots, where Minot Thayer was selling at Auction my wood standing upon the Land, chiefly Pine— I found there was a considerable number of persons assembled— Fifty-one lots for purchasers were laid out and about half of them had been sold— The prices were low, but it was not probable that more would be obtained by postponing the Sale; and Thayer the Auctioneer who was bewailing aloud the very low rate at which the lots were successively struck off, whispered to me immediately afterwards, that they would probably never sell better— I directed two of the best lots to be reserved for my own consumption, and spoke to William Spear, to cut the wood in the winter, and bring it to me in the Spring— I shall thus ascertain the average quantity of wood which is taken from each lot— A man named Ezra Beale who purchased several Lots, said he had purchased one last year from which he had taken 13. Cords of wood, and had paid 13. dollars for the Lot—and that it was the cheapest purchase of wood he had ever made— I believe the whole of my Sales last year, yielded me about that average—one dollar a Cord— And pinewood will not produce more— I came home about noon, and
after dinner went with John Kirke to Boston— First to my Son Charles’s House and at six O’Clock to Mrs M’lean’s N. 44. Beacon Street, where I was present at the ceremony of her marriage, with Mr William Lee, which was performed by the Revd. Mr Green— There was a peculiarity in this solemnization, which excited feelings and reflections different from those of any other wedding at which I had ever been present— The parties are each about three score years of age— I knew them both in the heyday of youth before either of them was first married— I then also knew their former Partners, now in the grave— The numerous family of the Amory’s in both branches were social companions of my youth. Of six brothers of the present bride, the three Survivors John, Rufus and Francis were now present, as was the youngest Sister Mrs Bethune with her husband— But Mrs Codman, and Mrs Lowell with her husband were not there— Mrs M’lean has no children; but about half the company present were of a subsequent generation—children of my old acquaintance. There were of the former generation also Daniel Davis, George Blake, John Gray, Joseph Russell— Jonathan Davis and his wife—H. G. Otis, who did not speak to me, and some others— Mr Lee’s Son Thomas was there, and Mr Green prayed for him and his Sisters, as part of the marriage Service— This was one of the singularities of the occasion— The couple thus united cannot have many years to live together— Their cotemporaries blooming in youth as I had seen them all, are now, some bending under the weight of years, and faces where I had seen roses in bloom, were now furrowed, wrinkled and haggard— I too have gone through a corresponding change, and was an object of meditation to them, as they were to me. Cupid and Hymen! what worshippers of yours are these! There was a numerous Evening party invited at 8. O’Clock; from which I made however my escape, and returned to Charles’s House, and thence home to Quincy which I reached thoroughly chilled as the moon was rising just after nine—
5— VI. Friday.

Resumed my Nursery Labours and planted three Cross rows East of the Alley with Washington Chesnuts, Acorns and Liquidamber Apples, with Druid Juglans— Penn’s Hill Red-streak and other Apple-seeds. My brother, and his Daughter Abigail dined with us. After dinner I had a visit from Dr Holbrook, with Coll Nathan Rice, now of Burlington in the State of Vermont, but in 1775. a Student at Law in the Office of my father; at Braintree, with John Thaxter and Jonathan Mason— Rice left the Office for the Army, in which he served several years but not till the end of the War— He lived many years afterwards at Hingham, his native place, whence he removed some years since, to the State of Vermont— The last time I had seen him was at Cambridge, at Commencement in 1828. He has been upon a visit to his friends in Hingham; and is now upon his return. My brother’s wife and her Son Joseph came for Abigail this Evening. William Spear brought me the book containing the minutes of the Sales of standing wood at the Railway lots yesterday— The wood sold I imagine at less than a dollar a cord—but it was chiefly Pitch and white Pine— I walked over the Trask Hills this afternoon, returning by the road— Yesterday I finished reading Cicero’s
Oration for Quintius, and this morning began that for Roscius of Ameria— When I began, reading the Orations last Spring I omitted these two, having recently read them before— I take them up now to complete the reading of all his Works in succession— That for Quintius has always been a favourite of mine, as the most splendid example of a subject dry and barren of itself rendered eminently interesting by the hand of the Master— It has the charm too of shewing the first developement of the Genius of Cicero. The consciousness of his Power—the ostensible alarm and real exultation at finding himself pitted against Hortensius— The smartness—the vivacity—the dramatized dialogue; the philosophical remarks and maxims of Morals so well and aptly introduced have always delighted me, and have perhaps given me as much pleasure as at the first reading.
6. IV. Saturday.

At the mount Wollaston farm, I planted with Chesnuts, Shagbarks and Acorns, the fourth side of the border round my projected Orchard, in five rows; which occupied Salmon Farrar, Alpheus Spear, his Son Charles Adams Spear, and me, great part of the morning. Some seeds of the Button wood, were also planted at Spear’s request— Read the Clock mender was there— I was short of Shagbarks, and called at Briesler’s shop for a new supply— Of a Barrell that he had, not more than a Pint and a half would sink in Water— Yet they have been kept in an open Barrell in a shop where there is no fire— This confirms all my preceding experience that these three kinds of seeds can be safely kept for planting only by covering them with damp earth or sand— My Acorns this day planted were those which I last gathered: probably too late in the Season— I attempt to keep, in damp sand, and earth a few Chesnuts and Shagbarks, to plant in the Spring— I came home to dinner, and returned to lay out the ground for the Orchard— Lemuel Spear was then there; with his brother— Measuring from the Eastern border, at the distances of two Rods each we marked the places for ten Trees, fronting the Road— Then Northward in a line parallel to the Eastern Border over fifteen furrows included within the Square places for 150 trees.— There was left on the Western side within the border space for four shortened rows, North and South, of 13. 11. 9. and 7. trees—say forty, and two short rows fronting the road, with 4. and 1.—whole number 195 trees— I proposed to Alpheus Spear to pick out for me at Mr Capen’s, twenty-five trees, for the alternate places on the outer rows of the Square, thinking that if he picked them himself he would have a personal impulse to tend them more carefully, but he declined choosing the trees, and said his brother Lemuel understood more about trees than he did.— I told them I should put pumice in the places of the alternate stands, to raise the Stocks from the Seed— Lemuel thought it would be less trouble to plant the pumice in a row, and transplant the trees after they should come up; but I want to have the trees stand for life, where they shall come up—and I propose to set out a part of these trees at this Season, and the rest in the Spring; to observe which of them will thrive best— My brother was here before dinner. The Newspaper of this Evening, brought the last returns of the Congressional Election for the District of Plymouth. Twenty-two Towns gave 2565 votes, of which 1817 were for John Quincy Adams, 373 for Arad Thompson (Jacksonite) 279 for William Baylies (federal,) and 96 scattering votes— The authentic returns will perhaps make some slight difference in the number of votes, but can make none in the result— I am a member elect of the twenty-second Congress.
7. V:30. Sunday.

My Son Charles came out from Boston, dined with us, and returned this Evening. I heard Mr Whitney in the forenoon from John 3.20. “For every one that doeth evil hateth the light, neither cometh to the light, lest his deeds should be reproved”—and in the afternoon from 1. Timothy 1.17. “Now unto the king, eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God, be honour and glory for ever and ever. Amen.” These were both old Sermons— Spent the Evening in writing; and reflecting upon this new incident which has drifted me back again amidst the Breakers of the Political Ocean— It is also a novelty in the history of the Country; and as a precedent may have no unimportant bearing upon future Events— By the Constitution of the United States, the President is re-eligible as long as he lives— Washington, Jefferson and Madison, voluntarily retired after one re-election—and Jefferson no doubt intended to make the example a practical exposition of Constitutional principle— It was followed by Mr Monroe, perhaps with not much cordiality; and will be continued as long as a Presidential Term of eight years shall wear out the popularity of the person holding the Office. One of the consequences of this has been and will be that Ex President’s will survive many years the termination of their Offices— That as individuals they will take a part in public affairs, and that they will sometimes solicit, and sometimes be elected to subordinate Offices— All the preceding President’s have held Offices of a public nature, after the expiration of their Presidential Service— None however as a member of either house of Congress; and there are many who think it now a derogatory descent— This is a mere prejudice; and had I alledged my former Station as a Reason for rejecting the suffrages of the People, assigning me a Seat in the House of Representatives, I should not merely have been chargeable with Arrogance, but should have exposed myself to ridicule. So far as concerns myself I consider this new Call to the public Service as a misfortune: inasmuch as it takes from me the last hope of an old age of quiet and leisure. I am still to be buffeted with political rancour and personal malignity; with more than equal chances of losing the favour even of those who now think they honour themselves by their suffrages more than me. My return to public life in a subordinate Station is disagreeable to my family and disapproved by some of my friends; though no one of them has expressed that disapprobation to me— For the discharge of the duties of this particular Station I never was eminently qualified; possessing no talent for extemporaneous public speaking; and at this time being in the decline of my faculties both of mind and body. This event therefore gives me deep concern and anxious forebodings. Yet can I not withhold my grateful acknowledgment to the disposer of human Events, and to the People of my native region for this unexpected testimonial of their continued confidence, after all the combinations of personal rivals, and political competitors to shake it— [“]The heart knoweth its own bitterness; and a Stranger, intermeddleth not with its joys”— No one knows, and few conceive the agony of mind that I have suffered from the time that I was made by circumstances, and not by my volition a candidate for the Presidency till I was dismissed from that Station by the failure of my Re-election— They were feelings to be suppressed, and they were suppressed—no human being has ever heard me complain— Domestic Calamity far heavier than any political disappointment or disaster can possibly be, overtook me immediately after my fall from power, and the moment of my distress was seized, by an old antagonist,
to indulge a hatred overflowing with the concentrated rancour of forty years; and who could not resist the pleasure of giving me what he thought the finishing blow, at the moment when he saw me down— It seemed as if I was deserted by all mankind, and precisely at that time the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, a Literary and Scientific Institution of my native State, which for a Series of years during my prosperity had annually elected me their President when it was impossible for me to attend their Meetings, thought proper to substitute another President in my place— In the French Opera of Richard Coeur de Lion, the minstrel Blondel, sings under the walls of his prison a song beginning

when I first heard this Song, forty-five years ago, at one of the first Representations of that delightful play, it made an indelible impression upon my memory, without imagining that I should ever feel its force so much closer home— In the year 1829. scarce a day passed that did not bring it to my thoughts— In the course of past Winter a vacancy occurred in the Board of Overseers of Harvard University— Absent, I was very unexpectedly elected to fill that vacancy— I attributed this to the personal friendship and influence of President Quincy— But this call upon me by the People of the District in which I reside, to represent them in Congress, has been spontaneous; and although counteracted by a double opposition; federalist and Jacksonite, I have received nearly three votes in four, throughout the district. My Election as President of the United States was not half so gratifying to my inmost Soul— No election or appointment conferred upon me ever gave me so much pleasure— I say this to record my Sentiments—but no Stranger intermeddleth with my Joys, and the dearest of my friends have no sympathy with my Sensations.
8. IV. Monday.

The dry blow has been variegated last Night, with a little Rain, and rain again this Evening; but I spent the morning after breakfast in my Nursery. Finished planting the cross furrows East of the Alley, with the Chesnuts and Acorns from Washington; mixed with Juglans Amara and dulcis, Shagbarks, Apple seeds and Stranger berries. Added one furrow length ways, from the young Apple tree upwards to the young Peach trees— Found a large bough broken and hanging down from my Shagbark tree in the Garden, which I planted Octr. 1804 I took it off with my handsaw, and will use it for index Stakes— My two years old red Oak is stripp’d of all its leaves. Two still adhere to the yearling below; but the leaves of the English Oaks have not yet begun to fall— Half of them retain their colour still— The rest are turning yellow— I finished reading the Oration for Roscius of Ameria this morning, and thus complete the perusal of the existing works of Cicero, begun last December— I read also that part of the Dedication of Ernesti to Stigliz, which is missing in my Copy of Ernesti’s second Edition— It is worthy of more than one reperusal— Had I forty years ago duly read this Dedication, and perseveringly devoted the leisure of one year without interruption to the Study of Cicero in his own language, my time would have been better occupied than it was, and perhaps my life might have been more useful to my Country and my fellow creatures than it has been— I gave too much of my youth to written translations—from Phaedrus, Suetonius, Caesar, Virgil, Horace, Cicero, Cornelius Nepos, Tacitus,
and Juvenal— Besides the still more unprofitable labour that I wasted upon German Translations—Wieland and Gentz—and Gellert— The Dedication to Stigliz is an argument in behalf of classical Literature, and embraces all that can be said in its favour— It treats with just contempt the idea that the eminent Greek and Latin authors are to be studied merely for the acquisition of the Languages— It considers the Classics as masters of morals; teachers of practical wisdom and virtue— It breathes the Spirit of Greece and Rome, and swells with the enthusiasm of Liberty and of intellectual Power— Of Cicero, I have more to say hereafter.
9. IV— Tuesday.

A stormy morning with rain which kept me within doors. Judge Hall, with Mr Bartlett called to see me—he told me they had been attending the probate Court for Norfolk County— Mrs Hall the judge’s wife died about a fortnight since of a pulmonary disease and his daughter is now in the last Stage of a consumption— He has consequently been for several months in deep distress, with those harrowing agitations under which one sees two of the dearest relations of human existence perishing by slow and irremediable degrees— As always happens in such cases, he has taken the impression that the medical treatment of the sufferers has been bad, and he told me of the manner somewhat harsh in which he had within a few days dismissed Dr Warren, with Dr Jackson, whom he had called in for consultation, and employed Dr Jeffers a much younger man in their place. Dr Jackson used to discover the state of Miss Hall’s lungs an instrument of French invention called a Stethoscope; but the alarm and agitation which its application caused, aggravated severely the symptoms of her disease, and induced the determination of the judge to take other advice— He flatters himself with a feeble hope, destined to disappointment: whether the change of treatment will hasten or retard by a few days the impending issue is uncertain— I had intended to attend the probate Court to-morrow, concluding that the judge would as usual sit again but after dinner, I took my papers with me to shew them to him, and found him on the point of adjourning his Court, without intending to sit to-morrow— I told him I wished to return again the Account which I had filed last year; filling the blank left for the allowance to the Executors with the amount fixed by his general Rule, two and a half per Cent on the property returned; and presenting the transactions since last year, in a subsequent and distinct Account, to which he assented— He thought there would be no occasion for a notice to all the parties interested in the Will, to authorise the allowance fixed by a general rule, and said there had been a recent decision of the Supreme Court, that the Settlement of an Executor or Administrator’s Account by a Judge of Probate whether with or without notice to all parties, might be subsequently revised. I told him that the Papers would require the signature of my Co-Executor, President Quincy, and that I would present them at the Court to be held the next Month at Dedham— I afterwards called for half an hour at my brother’s, who returned while I was there, having in the mean time been to my house— Last Evening I began reading to my wife, Galt’s Life of Lord Byron; which we continued this Evening—
10. IV. Wednesday.

Stormy weather continued, with intermission of the rain— I finished my plantations in my Nursery for this Season, with a cross-row, West of the Alley, planted with two rows of Juglans Amara, and one over them of Apple-seeds— I pruned some of my young Apple, Apricot, and Cherry trees—and took off one twig from the Red Oak— Cropped all the new shoots but one upon the willow in the Summer garden cellar— I seek experience, and every trifle in vegetation has become an important affair to me— As bodily exercise, the two hours a day that I have spent throughout the Season, at work with the Spade and Hoe, have been greatly serviceable to my health; and this is my apology to myself, for what seems to my friends a ridiculous waste of Time. Josiah Adams junr. was here this afternoon with his Bill, which I took ad referendum. Deacon Spear with his brother William came, and the Deacon, who has recovered from his Dogwood poisoning, paid me, about one third part of the proceeds of the Sales of standing wood and gave me his Note payable the first of May next for the remainder— I settled with him and his brother William, for their work done for me, and engaged William to cut and cart the wood upon the two lots reserved for my own use— The Deacon could not repress the overflow of his masonic feelings, and complained of the Resolutions of the Anti-masonic Convention which nominated me for the recent Congressional Election in Plymouth— I rode this afternoon to Dorchester, and called upon Mr Bailey— He finally wrote a Letter to one of the persons who attended the Norfolk District Convention, declaring that he did not wish to be considered a Candidate for Re-election; and General Dearborn has been chosen by a small majority in his place— The Antimasonic Candidate, Mr Thacher had a very strong vote in opposition to him, though Dearborn is not a Mason, and was supported by the Antimasonic party last Spring at the Senatorial Election— After my return this Evening, I continued reading of Galt’s life of Lord Byron.
11. IV. Thursday.

Storm continues with occasional rain; but not much this day. Alpheus Spear, brought a load of wood, and promised to bring another on Saturday, and two Loads of Seaweed to morrow— The weather is unpropitious too for fencing and planting at my orchard. I visited my Nursery—cropped a surface of weeds which never cease to grow, and opened two trenches between the rows of English Oaks, set out by my Son Charles— After dinner, I walked over the hills to the Atherton Pasture, in search of the wild Pear-tree from which I wished to procure seeds for Stocks— I was again disapointed not finding the tree— But in the adjoining Orchard I gathered a number of very small apples, from two trees bearing natural fruit, one the red streak from which I had already gathered some, the other a pale whitish crab— These are just now ripe, many of them still hanging on the Trees— These Apples though very small, are for the most part sound at the Core, and the seeds are in perfect condition— I propose to plant some of each of them with Stakes, designating their several kinds, and to watch their vegetation, and if so it may be, their production.— I gathered also a number of the bitter pignuts, fallen from the trees. Very few of these Nuts sink in Water— Most of them float under the surface, and those appear on cracking to have sound kernels; but very light, and withering easily.— The sweet
pignut is specifically heavier than the shagbark, and sinks in water like lead— I have read in Wells and Lilly’s Edition of Cicero, the general Preface of Ernesti to his Edition of 1772—a new preface, differing totally from that of his first Edition published in 1737.— In the original preface he gives an account of his motives to that undertaking, which was, by the advice of Gesner, a complete Edition of Cicero, from the text of that of Gronovius, revised with various readings from the Editions of Graevius, Davis and Pearce—without Notes, but with Arguments or Tables of Contents to the various books, mostly new, and with the Clavis, the design, motive and purpose of which he explains. But in this last Preface is a valuable Dissertation, first upon the principles of Criticism, which ought to be applied by an Editor of Cicero to his task, and then a statement how far they had been applied by those Editors who had preceded him— This includes a notice of the earlier Editions of all the remaining works of Cicero from that of Sweinhemius and Panartius at Rome in the 15th. century, to those of Gruterus, Hamburg 1618. and of Gronovius, Leyden 1692 from which his own first edition of 1737. was printed— For a more complete enumeration of the Editions of Cicero, he refers to his own Edition of the Bibliotheca Latina of John Albert Fabricius.
12. IV. Friday

The Northeast Storm which commenced last Saturday still continues— Last Night and throughout this day there were successive showers, with intermissions— My brother dined with us, and told me some curious anecdotes, about the masonic and anti-masonic snarl which is running like a poisonous weed over the Country— He says that the state of Mr Cutler’s health, is not the reason of his having parted from his flock. But he is a free mason; and was required by some of his principal supporters to renounce the craft or his parish, and chose the latter alternative— He spoke of several pamphlets relating to Moses Thacher, a clergyman, and seceding Mason, now a Senator in the State Legislature, and recently the Anti-masonic Candidate for the Norfolk District, to Congress— He also told me that in 1804. at Philadelphia, he was Counsel for a man, upon some Indictment— That his case was so desperate that he advised him to make no defence— That the man told him he would try the cause, and if there was a Mason upon the Jury he should get clear—which accordingly happened. He said Edward Miller, had shewn him some weeks since a Newspaper, containing a list of all the masons in this and several of the neighbouring towns— In squally weather we sometimes see Strata of clouds one, above another, and blown in directions opposite to each other— So it is with Masonry and Antimasonry; and there is what at one time was called a tertium quid, a counter check to Anti-masonry, consisting of persons not themselves Masons, but allied with them in opposition to Anti-masonry— This junction has decided the recent elections in the State of New-York— Mr Joseph P. Leland is a Nursery man, from Sherburne, who was disposed to sell me some fruit trees, of which I told him I might want some next Spring, but had no occasion for any now— I enquired his price, which he said for good trees was 30 Cents apiece; but he assured me that it did not pay for raising them— I asked if he engrafted upon Suckers: he said, not the trees for Sale— I asked what seeds he used— He said the seeds of fruit from
natural trees— That few of the Seeds from engrafted trees would come up, and those that did, were not so good for Stocks— He said he usually grafted upon Stocks the third, or fourth year from the seed, when they would sometimes grow six feet in one Summer. I read this Morning Ernesti’s preface to the Rhetorical works of Cicero, and the four Books addressed to Herennius— He says there is no Classical author of whom there are more antient manuscripts, and early Editions, than of the Rhetorics to Herennius; because there are none which in former ages were more studied; but that so great had been the change of taste, and so little were those books read in his time, that he grudged all the labour he had bestowed upon them, and was heartily rejoiced when he got to the end of it, aware as he was that it would be of little use to any one— On the other hand he was delighted with the occupation of revising the commenting upon the Books de Oratore, which he inclines to think the most perfect of the works of Cicero— I read also the dedication by Peter Victorius, to his friend Cavalcanti of his Castigationes in Ciceronem, of which I have a copy printed by Gryphius at Lyons in 1552— Sent John Kirke to Boston— Returned with flower Pots.
13. IV. Saturday.

The North-east storm continues; with increasing frequency of Showers— This is the eighth day of its continuance— It confined me all the morning to the House— After going through the Prefaces of Ernesti, I looked into separate Treatises which I have of two earlier Commentators upon Cicero—Paulus Manutius, upon the Epistles to Marcus Brutus and to Quintus Cicero, Printed at Francfort by Andrew Wechel 1580—and Andreas Schottus de Nodis Ciceronis Antwerp, printed by Gaspar Beller 1613— Also to the Specimen of outward Eloquence of Peter Francius—exemplified in the Oration for Archias—Amsterdam, Wetstein 1697. There are useful observations in all these books, but that which struck me most, and which I thought applicable to the excursive tendency of my reading at present, was the quotation by Peter Victorius of a quaint saying from a noble Greek Tragedian whom he does not name— πόνος, πόνω, πόνον φέρει (Labour, brings labour to labour.) So I returned to the Historia Ciceronis, by Francis Fabricius, first published at Cologne in 1564. and republished with the Elzevir Editions of Schrevelius; and with those of Ernesti and D’Olivet— But omitted from the republication of Ernesti’s Edition by Wells and Lilly— The History of Fabricius is divided into 64. chapters, one for each year of the Life of Cicero; and at the head of each chapter he gives the year of Rome the names of the Consuls of the year, and the corresponding age of Cicero— As I propose to persevere in the daily reading of Latin, I had thoughts of passing now to another author, and am balancing between Pliny junior, Caesar, Livy, Tacitus and Seneca. But I have not yet given one entire year to Cicero, and with Casaubon and Ernesti; I think two scarcely sufficient to read meditate and inwardly digest his works— I have yet to consult his commentators, Translators and expounders English, French and German— I received a letter from my Son John; and there was one to his mother— That to me corroborates the opinion expressed by Charles, and of which I was already convinced that the state of my affairs requires me to go, for part of the Winter to Washington— John’s Letter to his Mother, very earnestly urges that we should
go, and after reading it she said she would do as I should think proper. I answered John’s Letter, expecting to proceed after the 7th. of next month, when I must attend the Probate Court at Dedham— After dinner I walked to my brother’s, and returned before dark.
14. IV:30. Sunday.

The Storm with occasional Showers continues. Ninth day.— Heard Mr Whitney in the morning from Matthew 6.31. “Therefore take no thought, saying, what shall we eat? or what shall we drink? or wherewithal shall we be clothed?” and in the afternoon, from Mark 12.37. “And the common People, heard him gladly.” It was so dark that Mr. Whitney had great difficulty in reading his Sermons, and in the afternoon, was obliged to have one of the window blinds opened in the midst of his discourse. The whole Service occupied less than an hour each time— The morning Sermon was upon one of those passages in the new Testament, which discountenance the excess of worldly cares— Mr Whitney observed that though seemingly variant, it was not in reality inconsistent with other parts of Scripture which very emphatically recommend laborious diligence, and a watchful regard to worldly interests— There is indeed a very remarkable difference between the Instructions of Solomon in the Proverbs, and the lessons of Jesus to his disciples— The Proverbs are full of rebukes upon the Sluggard— Jesus forbids all taking thought of the morrow— Solomon refers to the example of the Ant— Jesus to the Lilies of the field; which neither toil, nor spin; though Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of them— Mr Whitney pointed out the correct meaning of the words of Jesus, which is a caution against excessive or carking care, and cited with approbation a recent translation of the Scriptures which in this passage renders the words of the original, by anxious care— The purpose of the precept is to enjoin trust in God, and Mr Whitney’s Argument was in the true Spirit of his text— He exhorted his hearers also to discard too anxious a thought for worldly goods, by estimating them at their true value; of little worth in comparison with spiritual blessings; and at the same time warned them not to neglect that sober, cheerful, and diligent regard for their own interests and the comforts of those dependent upon them, which has the sanction of the Scriptures as well as the Seal of all experience— The afternoon text prepared the auditory for a democratic discourse, but it was not invidiously so— It appeared to have been written some years since, and from the difficulties in the delivery that the Preacher had not very recently read it— In the Evening I finished reading to my wife, Galt’s Life of Lord Byron. This person has now been seven years dead, and the public interest in him has not abated— He was one of the wonders of his age, and was like Napoleon Buonaparte the Torso of a Hercules—A Grand Homme manqué. A club-footed Apollo, in mind as in person. There are sublime and beautiful passages of detail in his Poetry, and if he had finished his Don Juan, it would have been a worthy companion to Voltaire’s Pucelle, in the Temple of Cloacina, upon the summit of Parnassus— Galt had a slight acquaintance with him, having been for some time a fellow passenger with him on his first voyage to Greece, and feels kind to his Memory. He publishes this life of him because he says Moore’s has not been satisfactory to the
Public— This book is very amusing—seldom tedious, and has passages of fine writing— But he ranks Byron rather above Milton as a Poet, and is half-inclined to give him the Pas—before Shakespear. He shews that Byron was jealous of Shakespear, and that he was very indignant at being compared to Rousseau, because Rousseau was the Son of a watchmaker— He likens Byron to Raphael— If Raphael had introduced his own Portrait into every picture he ever painted; and given himself in every picture the attributes of some fine mad devil of Pandemonium, there would have been more resemblance between him, and the noble Poet.
15. IV:30. Monday.

A new Moon— The storm has abated and calm sultry weather with a thick fog has taken its place— No appearance of the Sun— Tenth day since he was visible— My wife was ill—confined to her chamber, and great part of the day to her bed with a severe cold, head ache, and threatened inflammation of the eyes— She applied leaches behind her ear. I visited my Nursery this Morning— All was desolation— Measured finally the tallest of the Apple-trees, which came up last Spring, from seeds which I planted in the Summer of 1829. not quite twelve inches— The rest shorter down to a single inch. If five of the fifteen live through the winter, it will be good fortune— I have planted a whole Squantum Apple—3. Gay Pear-seeds, 2 Druid Pear seeds, and 9 Penn’s Hill Crab seeds in one Earthen-ware flower Pot, with four Stakes to the four winds— The white-Oak Acorns, which I pressed down at the sides of the two Quart Tumblers on the 15th. of last Month have continued to sprout— Several of them have pushed their roots down to the bottom of the Tumblers, and are crossing there— Grown about six inches long in the Month— During the recent rains, I have left each of the Tumblers alternately, a Night and day in the yard: keeping the other in my chamber— I continue to read the Historia Ciceronis of Francis Fabricius, and this day read also part of the Article upon Cicero in Ernesti’s Edition of the Bibliotheca Latina, of John Albert Fabricius— He there mentions a Dissertation, by the Abbé Mongault, in the Memoirs of the French Academy of Inscriptions, upon the Fanum or Temple, which Cicero had projected to build in honour of his daughter Tullia— Which Dissertation I likewise read— Then the Prefaces of D’Olivet, and some pages of Gibbon’s History and of his Miscellaneous Works— It absorbed the Morning— After dinner I walked to my brother’s and returned him the pamphlets he had lent me upon the Masonic brawl. The report of the Committee of the Lodge at Wrentham against the Revd. Moses Thacher represents him in a very unfavourable light— There is a want of Principle as well as of Discretion in the conduct attributed to him— Passed this Eve, writing.
16. IV:30—Tuesday.

I went to Boston this morning with John Kirke; with the purpose of attending a Meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences— But on going to the Apartment of the Academy, N. 50. State Street, I found it locked up, and conclude that the Meeting was held last Tuesday, though I received a printed notice of it only last Thursday— I met Degrand in the Street, and he called at my Son Charles’s Office to consult my opinion, whether a War would break
out in Europe, before the next Spring— I thought not— Mr Curtis also called and returned to me the Letter from the Brothers Baring, relating to the affairs of William Vaughan, and the Bonds of Petty Vaughan as Administrator of Thomas Boylston and of Ward N. Boylston. Mr Curtis said he had at Mrs Boylston’s request consulted Mr Lowell, who was of opinion that nothing could be done— He spoke also of the unsuccessful attempt to sell Mr Boylston’s Neponset Bridge Shares; for which Daniel Greenleaf offered 500 dollars each, but Mr Curtis bought them in—but inclined to let Mr Greenleaf have them now, if he would take them at his bid— I promised to speak of it to Mr Greenleaf— I had prepared the Account and papers relating to the Execution of my father’s Will, to be submitted to the judge of Probate, at Dedham on the 7th. of next month: expecting to have met President Quincy my Co-Executor in Boston— He was not there, and I left the Papers which must be approved and in part signed by him, with my Son Charles— Dined with him; and examined the Oxford Edition of Cicero of 1783. of ten Quarto Volumes; and professing to be from the text of D’Olivet’s Edition— It has neither Notes nor Arguments— I took out with me the 10th. and 12th Volume, of Welles and Lilly’s reprint of the last Edition of Ernesti— These Volumes contain his Prefaces to the Volumes of the Epistles— I came home about Sunset— Elizabeth C. Adams had spent the day here, and was just going home— I received a Letter from Benjamin Vaughan, and one from Dr Waterhouse with two or three proof Sheets of his projected book upon Junius.
17. V. Wednesday.

In the Nursery I planted in two cross furrows at the Stony-barren— East of the Alley a row of Leghorn Wheat; with foxy rapes, and West, a row of Pinus Pinea with Juglans Amara— In a second Earthen ware flower-pot 5 Cores and 10. Seeds of Saint Germain Pears— A man by the name of M’Intire who said he belonged to Needham, brought for Sale 30 Russet Apple Trees four years grafted, which I purchased of him— He said the Spears, Alpheus and Lemuel, whom he had seen at Brighton, had told him I was wanting some trees, and as he was going about with some for sale, he had concluded to come round this way—never having been here before— I walked down to the Mount Wollaston farm— Alpheus Spear was not at home, but as I was returning home, I met Lemuel, and engaged him to send for the Trees to-morrow; and to get them set out as soon as possible— I answered Dr Waterhouse’s Letter, and sent back his proof Sheets, of the book he is publishing to prove that Lord Chatham was the author of the Letters of Junius— One of the Chapters that he sent me is a discursive Essay upon the characters of Samuel Adams, John Adams, and John Hancock. He produces however a number of parallel passages between the Letters of Junius, and the Speeches of Lord Chatham in Parliament about the same time, which are indeed very striking; but the same thing has been done before to fix the authorship of Junius upon Sir Philip Francis— I resumed again this day for about an hour the task of assorting my father’s papers— I have some difficulty in fixing a method by which they may all be arranged, and certainly cannot now get through with them before my departure
for Washington— I may perhaps assort those of the period during which he was President of the United States— In the Evening I received Letters from B. Vaughan of Hallowell, Edward Wyer, and my Son John— Joseph H. Adams came for his Sister Elizabeth—
18. V. Thursday.

Answered my Son John’s Letter before breakfast; by which I lost twenty pages of the Historia Ciceronis— In the Nursery I planted a row of Penn’s Hill Redstreak Apple seeds, with two Garden Shagbarks, which had remained on the tree till yesterday, between the row of this years Apple trees from the Seed, and Charles’s English Oaks— Also a row of Red streaks in Book box N. 2— The English Oak leaves, have changed to a light Chocolate colour and are falling off. Alpheus Spear brought a load of wood, and took down my purchase of 30. Russet Apples trees; which he is to set out on Saturday, if the weather should be fair— This morning was the thirteenth of Clouds and gloom, but the afternoon cleared off fine. In the assortment of my fathers papers I found the whole correspondence relating to the army of 1798. which was an intrigue of Alexander Hamilton’s, to get an army raised under the preposterous panic of an invasion from France; with himself at the head of the army, under the nominal command of Washington, whose countenance and influence were necessary to make the army palatable to the Nation— Hamilton had first wrought upon the feelings of Washington, to concur in this plan. Till Washington made it an indispensable condition of his own acceptance that Hamilton should be the first Major General under him— In the Revolutionary War Hamilton had borne no higher rank than that of a Colonel— Knox had been a Major General and Charles Cotesworth Pinckney had ranked above Hamilton— Knox had been since the Peace of 1783 Secretary of War both under the Confederation Congress, and under Washington, while President— But Washington now in the most peremptory manner insisted that both Hamilton and Pinckney should be placed above Knox. His will prevailed, and Knox refused to serve— Pinckney consented to serve under Hamilton, and offered to serve under Knox; but the arrangement was made at Washington’s Dictation, and the proposal was not made to Knox to rank between Hamilton and Pinckney. This transaction was the primary cause of the overthrow of the federal party, and of the failure of my father’s Re-election— The raising of the Army was an unnecessary, and unpopular measure— The appointment of Hamilton and Pinckney over the head of Knox, was a slight upon New-England— The army itself raised and maintained at an enormous expence, was perfectly useless when raised, and Hamilton to save his darling chance of commanding in chief the Army, was driven to desperation by my fathers taking away both the pretexts for keeping up the army—removing all pretence of a foreign War, by a Treaty with France, and all danger of internal commotion by pardoning the Insurgents of Pennsylvania— Hamilton first attempted to get Washington and then Pinckney up against my fathers re-election, and though he failed in both those projects, he split up the federal party and brought Jefferson in— The same insatiable itch for intrigue cost him at last his life, by the hand of Burr—
This afternoon I walked to Deacon Adams’s, but he had not returned from the Woods— I called then at my brother’s— Evening at home, and read Edward Everett’s Lecture upon the working men’s party.
19. V. Friday.

I intended to perform my last planting of Seeds in the Nursery for this Season— Between two Rows of Charles’s English Oaks I planted a row of half Penn’s Hill Crab, and half Atherton Crab Apple seeds—with two Garden Shagbarks— And at the bottom of the Nursery opposite the Alley, one Black Walnut in the drupe, which my brother gave me yesterday from a Tree on the grounds of Edward Miller— I pruned two of Charles’s Oaks— The last leaf had fallen, from the best of the two Oaks of this year growing on the borders of the Alley.— I have reserved a quantity of Shagbarks, Pignuts, Chesnuts and Apples to plant, if I have the opportunity in the Spring— I had given up all expectation of seeing vegetation from any seed that I had planted since the first of July, but this day a plant shewed itself in one of my Greenwood boxes in the Summer House cellar—not sufficiently developed to discover what it is— To prevent it from being immediately killed by the frost, I had it brought into my chamber, and the Earthen ware pot implanted with St. Germain Pear seeds carried out to supply its place— I sent John Kirke to Boston with Trunks and Chests of our baggage to be shipped for Washington in the Schooner Caledonia, Captain Eldridge. My brother dined with us— Towards Evening I walked to the cross Roads near Neponset Bridge, and found, by the Time in walking it that from the Draw to my house is two well measured Miles. Just equal to my morning walk round the Capitol at Washington— Returning I stopped at Mr Daniel Greenleafs, where I found Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf— Mr Lemuel Bracket came in shortly after— Mr Daniel Greenleaf agreed to take the six Shares of the Neponset Bridge Stock, which belonged to Mr W. N. Boylston, at the price which he offered for them at the Auction—505 dollars a share— They were all lamenting the Schism, which the Universalists are raising in Mr Whitney’s Parish— They have applied for the use of the Meeting House on Christmas day; and expect to obtain it by a vote of the Parish— I wasted a considerable part of this day, in a fruitless search for Benjamin Vaughan’s papers, which he has written to me requesting me to seal up and sent to Mr. Gideon Snow at Boston, with a promise that he will shortly send them to me again— A man by the name of Cobb came with a Subscription paper for republishing an abridgment of Crabbe’s Technological Dictionary, which I signed.
20. IV:30. Saturday—

Sent John Kirke into Boston this morning with the Carriage for Charles and his wife. Wrote to Charles and Mr Nathaniel Curtis— Went with Salmon Farrar to the Mount Wollaston farm, and there with Lemuel and Alpheus Spear, set out the thirty Apple-trees which I purchased last Wednesday— They are in Rows, nearly North and South nearest to the house— Four Rows alternately of eight and seven each— The alternate stands I planted with pomace and Apple-seeds, setting a stake in the centre where I propose the tree shall stand, and scattering round each Stake, 20 or 30 Apple-seeds mixing in each hill, with the pomace two or three seeds from Office Apples or Penn’s
Hill Redstreaks— Lemuel Spear told me that my Trees were four years old from the graft; and shewed me on the Stem and branches the growth of each year. He thought it would be much cheaper for me to set out the whole Orchard with such trees than to raise one half of the Stocks as I propose from the Seed— This no doubt is true— Should the Plantation of my Seeds and Pomace succeed, I cannot expect that the Trees from the seed will be more advanced in growth, in seven years from this time, than those which I now set out are already— In less than fifteen years none of them can be expected to bear their natural fruit—nor can I flatter myself that I shall live to witness this result of the experiment. But I may live to see the success or failure of the experiment; and possibly to make observations upon the growth of the Trees which may be useful hereafter to others. The future condition, relative strength fertility and duration of these two Classes of Trees may be remarked for a century to come, upon this single Orchard— The comparative growth and thriftiness of Oaks, Chesnuts, and Shagbark Hickories and Button woods, may be noted, by a glance at the same spot, less than five Acres in extent—while I have life and health myself I shall assiduously mark its progress and vicissitudes, and hope that the infection of curiosity and observation may pass to my Son Charles, or some other Successor, through whom it may finally result to the improvement of the Agriculture of the Country; and particularly to the cultivation of Forest and Fruit trees— I was anxious already to ascertain if any of the nuts and acorns which I planted the 23d. of last Month, had begun to take root, and with Alpheus Spear, I uncovered two of the Hills— In one of them we found an Acorn and Chesnut unaltered, and without sign of vegetation— In the other the Acorn had taken rank hold of the ground by a taproot— If one in ten that I planted takes root, the border will have in it the germ of a venerable grove which in a century from this day may cover the now naked Mount with Oaks as sturdy as those which more than two centuries since Captain Wollaston found upon it— The stumps of two or three of these, still decaying on the Western declivity, attest their gigantic stature when living; but an old cedar at the bottom of the North-eastern side, and an old Apple-tree on the decline of the ridge are the only trees now standing upon it— We finished our work for the day about half past two O’Clock, and I came home— Spear’s men were finishing the Rail-fence round the future Orchard while we were setting out the Trees and planting the Pomace and seeds— Charles and his wife came out while we were at dinner— Deacon Spear gave me a certificate.
21. IV:45. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney, in the morning from Ephesians 6.4. part of the verse— “Fathers, bring up your children in the Nurture and Admonition of the Lord.” In the afternoon from Psalm 90.10. “The days of our year, are three score years and ten; and if by reason of strength they be four score years, yet is their strength labour and sorrow: for it is soon cut off, and we fly away.” The duty of Parents to give a pious education to their children, and the shortness and misery of human life are themes always interesting and suitable to be presented by a Christian Minister to his People— Always worthy Subjects for exhortation— But they are not susceptible perhaps of much novelty of illustration, and Mr Whitney travelled in the beaten track. He read also the Governors
Governor’s Proclamation for the annual Thanksgiving on Thursday the 2d. of next Month. The Proclamation makes allusion to the downfall of the Turkish Government in Greece, and to the overthrow of that of Charles the 10th. in France— This morning I finished reading the Historia Ciceronis of Francis Fabricius; valuable chiefly as an Index for commencing with the birth of Cicero it devotes one Section to every year of his Life—naming the Consuls of every year; and all the remarkable facts relating to the person of Cicero, which occurred during the year— It marks the writings and Orations, assigning each of them to the appropriate year, and vouches not only the numerous passages of the Epistles and other writings of Cicero, in which he makes mention of himself, but also the passages of all the cotemporaneous and subsequent classical Latin authors, authenticating the other facts. This Historia Ciceronis was published about the year 1560. Middleton in the preface to his Life of Cicero, acknowledges that this work of Fabricius had eased him of a great share of the trouble of ranging his materials in their proper places— For a thorough mastery of the works of Cicero, Fabricius is a useful assistant— There is also a posthumous work of Christopher Cellarius, published by Michael Heusinger; by the title of a History—to assist in the exploration of the familiar Epistles part of which I read this morning.
22. IV:45. Monday

My Son Charles and his wife returned this Morning to Boston. There came on Rain just as they went away, which continued the whole day and Evening— Wind at Southeast—not much of a storm— Benjamin Bass came and requested me to leave the mortgage I have upon his house with some one here; as he hopes in the course of the Winter to borrow money and pay it off— I told him I would leave it with my Son Charles— Benjamin is a talker, and sat with me an hour and a half conversing upon his brother Isaac’s farm, and upon the Sale of wood on the stump— He says the family are averse to Isaac’s selling me, any of his Land adjoining mine, because they want to keep it in the name; it being an old hereditary Estate and that Isaac will certainly not sell any part of it for less than he asked of me— I was confined to the house by the weather. John Kirke returned from Boston with the Carriage while we were at dinner, and said he had brought out my brother with his daughter Abigail—he having met with a bad accident; which had well nigh proved fatal to him. He took his daughter to Boston with a hired horse and Chaise; intending to go to Medford— He had left her at Mr James H. Foster’s, and on turning the Corner of Hanover Street at Concert Hall, struck the wheel of a waggon with such violence, that both the Shafts of his Chaise broke off; the body came down upon him: he slipp’d through the side of the boot onto the pavement. The Chaise was over set, one of the wheels passed over his body, and the Chaise dragg’d on by the frightened horse broke down the bow window of a shop in the Street, and shattered a Lamppost before it— In falling my brother received also a contusion and cut at the back of his head— The horse was not injured— Immediately after dinner I went to my brother’s, and found that by the blessing of Providence he had not been very severely injured— His escape was almost miraculous— How he got through between the boot,
and body of the Chaise, onto the pavement, he does not know, and had the wheel passed over him, in any other direction than as it did, it must have killed him on the spot or broken both his legs— It passed over the thick of the thigh on one side, and the hip on the other, without grazing the chest— Dr Parkman happened to be near the spot where the accident happened—upon examination by him, and afterwards by Dr Randall it was found that no bone was broken— He was taken first to Mr Foster’s, and our Carriage being in Town, brought him and his daughter home— He has no small number of Scratches, but apparently no deeper harm— I met Dr Woodward at the door of his house, who thought he would not be confined more than one or two days— In the evening I began reading to Mrs Adams Moore’s Life of Lord Byron, but was soon obliged to desist.
23. IV. Tuesday.

One fair day. I finished reading the Historia of Cellarius, and returned to the Article upon Cicero, in Ernesti’s Edition of the Bibliotheca Latina of John Albert Fabricius— I read also the prefaces of Ernesti to the Epistles ad familiares and to Atticus, Quintus Cicero and Marcus Brutus— Ernesti says that no books of Cicero have been so much read as the familiar Epistles and none so little as those to Atticus— The causes of which he states to be the peculiar fitness of the former for teaching at once the Latin Language, and the Epistolary Style; and the extreme difficulty of the letter—written in half sentences, and often with studied obscurity—to which I added the perpetual recurrence of Greek words— I had thoughts of taking up now the Epistles of Pliny, and borrowed from the Town’s Library the Quarto Edition by Longolius, for the sake of the large Type; but did not begin it— I planted in the Nursery; at the Stony-barren, East of the Alley one cross-row of pomace but upon attempting to open a cross-row westward found the ground beneath the surface so choaked up with Stones that I was fain to call for the spade the Crowbar, and S. Farrar to get them out— I then made him take up fourteen of the seventeen young Apple-trees, clustered on the spot where four years ago, a heap of Pomace was cast, and replanted twelve of them in a row, about four feet apart from each other—and two on the Western side under shelter of the Wall— He took up also four of the three years old peach trees, and set them out in the garden— These are among the remnants of the wreck of my first seed and Stone plantations— They are discouraging— Every one of the Peach-trees had a worm preying upon its vitals at the root; which though cut out and destroyed, casts ominous conjecture upon the fate of the Trees next Spring and Summer— The Apple-trees are barely alive; wretchedly misshapen things, and such as a Seedsman would think only fit to be thrown away—but they are the best yet living of my plantation here— I had one uncommonly successful Season at Washington; but was then taken away from my plants; while the main body of my seeds here were sown upon Stony ground, and perished because they would not take Root— I am still prepared for disappointments, and hope only to persevere in defiance of them— I walked to my brother’s after dinner, and found him recovering from his accident— Mrs Lucy Dawes, and Mrs Howe, (who was Mary Norton,) were there— Returning home observed a Circle round the Moon; portending foul weather— Read Moore’s life of Byron in the Evening.
24. IV. Wednesday.

North-East Storm—realized the threat of the large circle round the Moon. The early morning lowered and blew, without rain— With Salmon Farrar, I took up eight 3 years old Peach trees, and set them out in the Garden— All of them had worms at the root, excepting two from which they had been extracted in the Summer— Rain came to aggravate the Storm and I postponed the further transplantation of my trees. Remainder of the day confined to the house by the Storm—waded along in the Article of Cicero in the Bibliotheca Latina of Fabricius— He referred to the 5th. and 6th chapters of the vindication of Cicero from calumnies by Andreas Schottus, which I read— These relate to the charge against him, that he was sarcastic and given to ridicule, as he undoubtedly was— Schottus was a Jesuit and defends him gravely. Ridicule is one of the most powerful weapons of eloquence; beyond all measure more powerful than invective— I have also nearly read through a Quarto Volume of Fragments, illustrative of the Bible, added to the English Translation of Calmet; a work adorned with numerous Copper Plates— The anonymous author is self sufficient, and I begrudge the Time I am wasting upon his lucubrations. For the last week I have been reading his new version of Solomon’s Song, which he represents as a Dramatic Eclogue divided into six days; the principal Personages of which are Solomon and Pharaoh’s daughter—each with a train of attendants— The History of Solomon informs us that he wrote a thousand Songs, of which this alone has been preserved— As an Oriental Epithalamium it is exquisitely beautiful; but it is idle to think of reducing it to the standard of European poetry, antient or modern, and in the mystical meaning attributed to it by some theologians I have little faith— The exposition of it by the Translator of Calmet is not satisfactory to me— He has improved upon the common translation in a few passages, and by shewing that some of the expressions hitherto applied to naked beauties are mere allusions to the attire of the party, has expurgated the most exceptionable parts of the book— Two hours of the Evening were spent in reading Moore’s Life of Lord Byron.
25. IV:30. Thursday.

This has been a terrific day: and if so here, must have been a fatal day to many upon the coast— I found when I rose John Kirke and S. Farrar up, and ready to go to Medford for the fruit trees as had been agreed with Charles, there was a heavy gale from the Northeast, and a little rain— I advised Kirke not to go; but he said it looked as if it would clear up and they went. The rain and the wind continued increasing the whole day, till it was little short of a hurricane— In the afternoon, I was obliged to darken my chamber by shutting the blinds of my Eastern Windows, and to light a lamp before four O’Clock. Confined to the house, yet wrote nothing excepting in this book— Reading Miscellaneous— Fabricius’s Account of the various Editions of Cicero’s works, was not amusing. I betook myself to Pliny’s Epistles, and read eight of them in the Edition of Longolius— Also Lord Orrery’s English Translation of them, with his
commentary upon each Letter— The Letters are of a character altogether different from those of Cicero; but are equally characteristic of the age in which they were written—and of the Government then existing— Written for the publication, or at least for preservation. Every Letter is a Dissertation, and they are full of ingenious reflections and virtuous Sentiments— The first to Septitius Clarus is a dedication to him of the collection, formed at his request— The fifth to Vaconius Romanus is a bitter invective against Marcus Regulus the infamous Prosecutor under the Reign of Domitian of Rusticus Arulenus— Pliny’s Letter was written shortly after the Death of Domitian, and he relates a base attempt of Regulus, to ensnare him by captious questions; his own evasions, and the anxious solicitude of Regulus since the accession of Trajan, for a reconciliation with Pliny— The sixth is a Letter to Tacitus, about boar hunting, and the 8th. is to Pompeius Saturninus, asking his critical remarks upon an Address to the Magistrates of Comum, by Pliny, upon his dedicating a Library to the use of the Inhabitants of that place— The Translation by John Lord Orrery, has more of the stiffness, than of the grace or point of the original— It is addressed to his Son Lord Charles Boyle, and indicates honourable purposes and amiable feelings— There is another English Translation by Melmoth— Harvey Field was here, and settled with me for his Rent the present year— He offered me 100 dollars for the house and two of the lot, now occupied by him for the next year. I told him I thought it worth more; but I am to give him an answer before the middle of March— Kirke and S. Farrar returned in the Evening from Medford, with 80 Apple trees, and a Letter from Mr P. C. Brooks— I read aloud near three hours in Moore’s Life of Lord Byron.
26. III.30. Friday.

About Midnight last Night, the Sky cleared off and it was for a short time calm— But it soon clouded up again and the gale recommenced, with abated violence— It continued with dark and gloomy weather the whole of this day. I took the six Certificates of Neponset Bridge Stock which had belonged to Mr W. N. Boylston to Mr Thomas Greenleaf, and there executed for my part the transfer of them to Mr Daniel Greenleaf, as had already been done by my Co-Executors Mrs Boylston and Nathanl: Curtis, and then took them to Mr Daniel Greenleaf to whom I delivered them— Mr Curtis had proposed to meet Mr Greenleaf at my Son Charles’s Office this day at Noon, but the weather imprisoned me all day yesterday—the transfer could therefore only be completed this day, and Mr Greenleaf promised to go and meet Mr Curtis to-morrow— Going to Mr T. Greenleaf’s I picked up from the ground near his house two small berries, which were of the same kind, with those of which I have planted a number, and called them stranger berries. Looking up I saw a tree in full bearing of the same berries standing in the road near the Wall— I shewed the berry to Mr Daniel Greenleaf and asked him if he knew what it was— After tasting it he said it was a Juniper berry, and referring to the tree
whence they had fallen, said that many years since, a man named Tyrrell then living had shewn him that tree then small, and told him it was a Juniper tree, and the only one in the Town of Quincy— But he observed, first that the berry was not quite ripe, and then that it had a stone, whereas the Juniper berry has seeds— And he said that when a boy, the French fleet, being in Boston he had passed days and Nights in boiling down Juniper berries to an Electuary for medicinal use by the Surgeons of that fleet. But Tyrrell’s information was erroneous— The tree is not a Juniper; nor is the tree the only one of its kind in Quincy— I must still call the fruit a Stranger; though being a Stone fruit, it is not a berry. In the afternoon I walked to my brother’s and found him recovering from his accident— Numerous flocks of wild geese passed over, this day— Whence come they? whither were they going? and what is the distance to them of a day’s Journey?— I read 8 Epistles of Pliny with Lord Orrerys Translation, and 30 pages of Moore’s life of Byron in the Evening.
27. IV:30. Saturday.

The Sky was swept of its clouds in the course of the Night, and this day was clear and cold Sunshine with a brisk Northwester. John Kirke and Farrar brought from Medford, Thursday Evening 80 grafted Baldwin Apple— Excepting one which proved to be a natural, ungrafted tree— Yesterday Kirke took them to Alpheus Spear’s, and this morning I went there with S. Farrar, a basket full of pomace, and six being the remnant of the Woodhouse or Office Apples which I had kept from the 17th. of August for the Seed— Alpheus Spear was going to Boston, but Lemuel and a workman were already setting out the Trees— In the course of the day, Spear and his man set out 70 of the Trees, while Farrar and I were planting the alternate stands for the Trees with Pomace and Seeds— At One O’Clock we came home to dine and for a fresh supply of Pomace. We returned before three, and finished at the dusk of the Evening— The Orchard is now completed— One hundred Apple-trees are set out, with ninety seven alternate Hills planted with Pomace and Apple-seeds, with the purpose and wish that in the twentieth century, which with the blessing of God—my Grand-children may live to see, an Apple-tree from a seed planted by my hand, may bear not forbidden fruit, upon every one of the Hills— Mount Wollaston has belonged to my Ancestors and to me about 190 years—that is from the Settlement of Braintree to this day— It was covered at first with Oaks of the Forest— One old Apple-tree is now its only shelter from the Storm— It is now pregnant with at least ten thousand seeds of fruit and forest, mostly planted by my hand, and in a century from this day may bear timber for the floating Castles of my Country, and fruit for the subsistence health and comfort of my descendants. To all which the blessing and sanction is indispensable, of the giver of all Good, and which with humble diffidence and hope, I invoke. Abigail S. Adams dined with us, and rode out with Mrs. Adams after dinner.
Mr Daniel Greenleaf called in the Evening, and brought me a Note from Mr Nathaniel Curtis, with whom he completed the transfer of the Neponset Bridge Shares— I finished reading the first Book of Pliny’s Letters with Orrery’s Translation this Morning, and read two hours of the Evening in Moore’s Life of Byron— There were ten of the Medford Apple-trees left, which Farrar brought back from the Mount, and which I propose to set out near my house.
28. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Bowes Whitney this Morning, from Ezekiel 18:9— “He is just, he shall surely live, saith the Lord God.”—and in the afternoon from Matthew 13:16— Mr Whitney dined with us; and Mr Degrand who came out from Boston. After the Evening service I went with him to my brother’s, and found him almost recovered from the effects of the bad accident which befell him last Monday— Mr Thomas Greenleaf and Mr Beale spent part of the Evening here; as well as Mr John Bailey, and Mr Morton of Milton, who is a very zealous anti-mason. He was one of the Delegates at the National Convention held in September last at Philadelphia.— The Anti-masonic fever assumes a variety of aspects, and is destined to produce extraordinary Effects upon the political Institutions of this Country— The Masons and Anti-masons are already organized as two opposite great political parties, and they are much embittered against each other— The Anti-masons, avow the principle of refusing their votes for any public office whatever to any member of the Order— Their Candidates are strictly Anti-masonic— There has always been a strong latent influence of Masonry operating upon Elections, but it has been generally been disclaimed, and often passed unperceived. It can now no longer be concealed or disguised— At the recent Election in the State of New-York the issue throughout the State was controuled by the Masonic contest alone. 120000 votes were cast for Granger the Anti-masonic Candidate for Governor— The Election was carried against him by a majority of only 8000 votes: and a much greater number than that were given by Masons opposed on all other grounds to the successful Canditate, but who sacrificed all other opinions and prejudices to prevent the Anti-masonic triumph— And they did prevent it— Anti-masonry is however now so fully organized that it will probably prevail in the New-York Elections, in one or two years— It is remarkable that the Antimasonic fermentation has spread only in the States where there are no Slaves— At the general Antimasonic Convention held at Philadelphia last September, there were delegations from most of the Northern States, and scarcely any from those of the South— It has been my endeavour to keep myself wholly aloof from this question— I have not however been permitted to remain neutral to it, and in more than one instance have felt the secret operations of Masonic animosity and resentment— The great danger of Anti-masonry is in its combinations with other political parties, and in the uses which faction may make of it— But the Spirit is up, and will not soon be
29. V. Monday.

Peter Turner called here this morning, and I had a discussion with him upon the comparative merits of certain Boots and shoes of his making— He took my box of shaving implements to make a leather covering for it— Joseph Hardwick came and made me an offer of 70 dollars for a year’s Rent of the house in which he lives— He gives 100 dollars for this year, and that has been the Rent paid by the Curtis’s for eight or ten years before— But rents in Quincy have fallen— I told him he might have the house, without the privilege of the barn, for 80 dollars; but he declined taking it at that rate— So it rests till next March. I received a Note from Mr Bailey, with a printed copy from Mr Morton, of the Proceedings of the United-States Anti-Masonic Convention, held at Philadelphia 11. Septr. 1830. and a request that I would lend Mr Morton, the book I had last night mentioned—Les Francs Maçons Ecraséz; but on looking over my library, I could not find it— It has like many others disappeared and I know not even where to enquire for it— The day was lowering, but permitted a visit to my Nursery and Garden. I took up 8 young Peach and 3.
